title: How to Write Basic SQL Statements in SQL Server

steps.title: Click on Start --> All Programs --> Microsoft SQL Server (2005/2008) --> SQL Server Management Studio
steps.content: Click on Start --> All Programs --> Microsoft SQL Server (2005/2008) --> SQL Server Management Studio

steps.title: Next Login with your credentials to the Server
steps.content: Next Login with your credentials to the Server

steps.title: Now right click on the Northwind Database and choose New Query
steps.content: Now right click on the Northwind Database and choose New Query

steps.title: In the new Query Window, enter the following command for SELECT
steps.content: In the new Query Window, enter the following command for SELECT

steps.title: This is the syntax for SELECT - SELECT * FROM Employees
steps.content: This is the syntax for SELECT - SELECT * FROM Employees

steps.title: This is the syntax for INSERT - INSERT INTO Employees VALUES('col1', 'col2') - Replace col1 and col2 with actual Values as shown below INSERT INTO Employees values('Anil','anil@company.com') This inserts a single row into the table.
steps.content: This is the syntax for INSERT - INSERT INTO Employees VALUES('col1', 'col2') - Replace col1 and col2 with actual Values as shown below INSERT INTO Employees values('Anil','anil@company.com') This inserts a single row into the table. In the even you wish to enter multiple rows at one go, you see the following command INSERT INTO Employees values('Anna','anna@company.com'), INSERT INTO Employees values('Krystel','krystel@company.com'), INSERT INTO Employees values('Lines','lines@company.com'). The key difference here is that every value is appended by a comma
